I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the Country Programming Mission from 2 to 19 July 2006, the Government of 
Bangladesh  (the  Government)  requested  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  provide 
assistance  for  promoting  private  sector  participation  to  support  sustainable  power  sector 
development. ADB conducted the Fact-Finding Mission (the Mission) from 5 to 11 September 
2006 to reach an understanding with the Government on the impact, outcome, outputs, cost 
estimates, financing, implementing arrangements, and the consultants’ terms of reference of the 
proposed technical assistance (TA).1  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Over the past decade, Bangladesh has taken great strides in its economic and social 
development. Yet, nearly half of the population remains poor, with per capita gross domestic 
product of $445 in 2005. Only a third of households have access to electricity and this minority 
receives a poor, unreliable service characterized by frequent power outages and low voltage, 
resulting from insufficient power generation and supply capacity. Inadequate supply of electricity 
has  been  a  major  constraint  to  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction  in  Bangladesh. 
Promotion of sustainable economic growth—by providing reliable power supply—is the main 
strategic pillar for reducing poverty in ADB’s country strategy and program for 2006–2010.2  
 
3.  Recognizing  that  investment  requirements  for  the  power  sector  would  exceed  the 
resources available in the public sector, the Government took a policy decision in 1994 to 
pursue private sector led development. A long-term policy paper in 1994 titled Power Sector 
Reforms in Bangladesh (PSRB) outlined the reform process to gradually remove constraints in 
the sector through promotion of private sector participation, among others. In 1996, with the 
support of ADB and other development partners (DPs), the Government set out the Private 
Sector Power Generation Policy (PSPGP) to introduce independent power producers (IPPs). In 
1998, the Government formulated Policy Guidelines for Small Power Plants in Private Sector 
and licenses have been issued to three small power plants developed by the private sector. In 
2006, the Government issued a 3-year road map for power sector reforms. One of the main 
strategic pillars is promoting private sector participation through, among others, formulating 
public-private partnership (PPP), e.g., joint venture finance in generation. 
 
4.  Until  the  late  1990s,  mainly  because  of  the  above  policy  framework  and  favorable 
market conditions, Bangladesh had been successful in attracting the private sector—particularly 
in generation where ADB played a catalytic role. Since the PSRB was introduced, IPPs have 
established new capacity totaling 1,290 megawatt (MW) over a total of seven plants, producing 
about  38%  of  current  total  national  generation.  ADB  recently  evaluated  its  power  sector 
assistance  program  in  Bangladesh3.  The  study  recognized  that  the  IPP  project  has  been 
operating  successfully  and  producing  power  at  reasonable  cost  to  Bangladesh  Power 
Development Board (BPDB) with a high level of reliability.  
 
5.  However, Bangladesh has recently been facing difficulties in mobilizing further private 
capital, as is the case in other developing countries. A worldwide trend shows that private 
investors’ interest in IPPs in developing countries has fallen off, and the number and value of

transactions sponsored by these investors are well below their peak in 1997. Several factors are 
generally considered to contribute to the falloff, including: (i) financial crises (e.g., the Asian 
financial crisis in 1997 featured steep devaluations of local currencies that undermined the 
sustainability of investments); (ii) conditions in international capital markets and the drop in 
investors’ market capitalization values affected their ability to raise capital for new investments; 
and (iii) concerns have been raised about the stability and enforceability of the legal and 
regulatory framework in power sector reform.  
 
6.  Among  these,  enforceability  of  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  is  needs  to  be 
strengthened in Bangladesh. Several attempts to award contracts for new IPP projects in the 
last few years have not been very successful, partly because of insufficient competition with less 
international participants under unfavorable capital market conditions, and partly because of 
perceived irregularities in procurement procedures. Local investors also tend to be discouraged 
from participating in IPP bidding in the absence of an appropriate regulatory framework and 
requirements of high capital investment.  
 
7.  Another  challenge  is  to  create  opportunities  for  various  kinds  of  private  sector 
investment from large-scale international syndicates to community-based small businesses. 
PPP is expected to lower entrance barriers, reduce risks, and leverage capital if it is properly 
designed and implemented. In this regard, the power sector in Bangladesh has been making 
efforts to formulate PPP, e.g., a joint venture between BPDB and the private sector. However, 
no successful PPP models have been realized so far. BPDB recognizes that an explicit PPP 
policy and regulatory framework need to be developed.  
 
8.  PPP has been continuously evolving with the latest financial structuring methods and 
risk mitigation measures in the fields of large-scale infrastructure development. There is a need 
to review various models and identify suitable ones for the power sector in Bangladesh. 
 
9.  In addition to generation, the distribution subsector also has great potential for private 
sector participation. The positive market response to recent listing of the shares of the Dhaka 
Electric Supply Company Limited (DESCO) in the local stock market represents the interest of 
the local private sector to enter the distribution business. At the operational level, DESCO has 
attempted various private sector participation approaches, including outsourcing commercial 
activities to the private sectors. However, in the absence of an adequate policy for private sector 
participation in the distribution subsector, implementation of these initiatives is limited to an 
entity level and is on an ad hoc basis. To enhance the financial viability of the whole distribution 
subsector  through  application  of  best  practices,  a  comprehensive  policy  framework  for 
promoting private sector participation covering all the power subsectors needs to be developed.   
 
10.  ADB has supported evolving private sector participation in the Bangladesh energy sector. 
Major  lessons  learned  from  earlier  ADB  TAs  will  be  incorporated  in  the  implementation 
arrangements under this TA. Important lessons include the need for a transparent and clear 
international competitive bidding process, and the importance of clear project definitions.    
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The TA aims to facilitate further private sector entries and investments, or PPP financing, 
for power sector projects in a flexible, efficient, and transparent manner, thereby contributing to 
enhanced  and  sustainable  electric  power  supply  in  Bangladesh.  The  TA  will  help  the

3
Government to update PSPGP and formulate enforceable regulations to be tailored to the local 
market environment. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The  proposed  TA  will  review  and  analyze  current  constraints  and  bottlenecks  for 
promoting  private  sector  participation,  including  PPP  initiatives  in  the  power  sector  in 
Bangladesh. Based on the analysis, the proposed TA will provide an institutional framework and 
recommendations for new policy initiatives and reforms for private sector participation in the 
power sector. PPP guidelines, several PPP models in generation and distribution subsectors 
policy guidelines will be also prepared to assist government officials and relevant agency staff.  
 
13.  To  develop  a  practical  policy  framework,  guidelines,  and  models  applicable  to 
Bangladesh, the TA will take a participatory approach to reflect inputs from all stakeholders, 
including the Government and its agencies, labor unions, beneficiaries, investors, operators, 
suppliers, financiers, consumers, and DPs. The TA recommendations will be disseminated and 
explained to government officials and agency staff.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $750,000 equivalent. ADB will finance $600,000 
on a grant basis from the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The 
Government will finance the remaining $150,000 equivalent in kind through the provision of 
administrative setup, including office space, office equipment, and local transportation. Detailed 
cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The Executing Agency (EA) will be the Power Division of the Ministry of Power, Energy 
and Mineral Resources (MPEMR). BPDB will provide technical and administrative support to 
MPEMR and will provide technical advice and suggestions to a consulting team to be recruited 
under the TA, as well as logistical support and coordination with various stakeholders. The 
Power Division of MPEMR will designate a project director and will set up a steering committee 
to supervise implementation of the TA. It is envisaged that the steering committee will consist of 
representatives from MPEMR and other agencies concerned, including BPDB. The committee 
will discuss the TA outputs, provide feedback and guidance to the consultants, and suggest how 
to implement the TA recommendations in practice. The Power Division of MPEMR will assume 
the secretariat function of the committee. 
 
16.  The EA and BPDB will provide (i) office accommodation and facilities, internet access, 
and secretarial support; and (ii) land transportation within Bangladesh for consultants. The EA, 
BPDB, and agencies concerned will also provide the consultants with existing data, preliminary 
analysis,  and  reports;  and  will  guide  consultants  in  data  collection  in  liaising  with  other 
government  ministries  and  agencies.  MPEMR,  BPDB,  other  relevant  agencies,  and  the 
consultants  will  jointly  organize  dissemination  workshops  for  counterpart  staff  and  other 
stakeholders. The EA will ensure close coordination with the consultants of various ongoing TAs 
of ADB and other DPs. The consultants will incorporate lessons from past TAs of ADB and other 
DPs in the power sector. The consultants will organize workshops, seminars, and consultation 
meetings to brief stakeholders and receive their feedback on the policy update, PPP guidelines, 
and the proposed PPP models in collaboration with ADB, MPEMR, BPDB, and distribution 
companies. The consultants will be accountable to both ADB and the EA.

4   
 
17.  The TA will require about 14 person-months of international and 20 person-months of 
national  consulting  services.  Appendix  3  provides  the  outline  terms  of  reference  for  the 
consultants. The TA will be implemented over 8 months from February 2007 to September 2007. 
ADB will engage a consulting firm or consortium of firms in accordance with its Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants. Recruitment of consultants will be under the quality and cost based 
selection procedures, and simplified technical proposals will be requested.  
 
18.  The  consultants  will  submit  an  inception  report  no  later  than  2  weeks  after  the 
commencement of their services. An interim report will be submitted within 10 weeks after 
inception and a draft final report will be submitted within 16 weeks after inception.  The inception 
report will detail initial findings and the consultants’ proposed action plan. The first tripartite 
meeting between the Government, ADB, and the consultants will review the inception report in 
Dhaka within 3 weeks of receiving it. An interim report will describe the TA’s progress, person-
months  utilized,  problems  encountered,  and  proposed  revision  of  the  work  plan;  and  will 
incorporate detailed reports on completion of the current policy analysis. A draft final report will 
detail the consultants’ findings and recommendations. The second tripartite meeting will review 
the interim report and the third tripartite meeting will review the draft final report. The consultants 
will organize: (i) two workshops after the second and third tripartite meeting to brief stakeholders 
and receive their feedback on the policy update, PPP guidelines, and models; and (ii) a seminar 
at the conclusion of the TA to disseminate the findings. The final report will be submitted within 
4 weeks after the tripartite review of the draft final report. The consultants will prepare monthly 
status reports for their specific scope of work, highlighting any issues that could become critical 
for the timely completion of the TA.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bangladesh for Promotion of Private Sector Participation in the Power 
Sector, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3    7 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
  
1.  The Government of Bangladesh (the Government) plans to update the Private Sector 
Power Generation Policy (PSPGP) to broaden its scope covering the entire power sector and 
public-private  partnership  (PPP).  Under  the  updated  policy,  explicit  guidelines  on  PPP  will  be 
provided to various stakeholders including the Government, power sector entities, and the private 
sector.  The  Bangladesh  Power  Development  Board  (BPDB)  and  other  relevant  power  sector 
entities are expected to process PPP projects under the updated policy and regulatory framework.  
 
2.  The international power sector development specialist, who will also serve as a technical 
expert, will be designated the team leader, responsible for the overall management of the study. 
The team leader will coordinate the technical assistance (TA) among all government agencies 
concerned, Asian Development Bank (ADB), and other development partners (DPs) to ensure 
smooth implementation and non-duplication of work, and will ultimately be responsible for all 
deliverables of the TA study. Other consultants will assist the team leader’s tasks specified below.  
The team leader will also closely coordinate with the consulting teams of other relevant studies of 
ADB and other DPs. 
 
3.  The  consulting  firm  to  be  engaged  under  the  TA  will  provide  experts  with  relevant 
experience in developing policy for promoting private sector participation and PPP, power sector 
reform, relevant legal and regulatory framework, financial structuring, and experts with extensive 
knowledge of the power sector in Bangladesh.  
 
4.  In close collaboration with the Power Division of the Ministry of Power, Energy and Mineral 
Resources (MPEMR), Bangladesh Power Development Board (BPDB), other relevant agencies, 
and the steering committee to be established by the Government, the consultants will undertake, 
but not be limited to, the following tasks. 
 
A.  Power Sector Development Expert, Team Leader (international, 8 person-months) 
 
5.  The terms of reference are as follows:  
 
(i)  Analyze existing power sector policies, including PSPGP and the Policy Guidelines 
for Small Power Plants in Private Sector; the legal and regulatory environment; 
enforceability  of  the  legal  and  regulatory  documents;  and  other  issues  and 
constraints that private investors and financiers may face. 
(ii)  Summarize  the  policy  and  regulatory  framework  related  to  private  sector 
participation  and  PPP  in  the  power  sector  of  developed  countries  and  other 
developing countries in the region, conduct a comparison analysis, identify best 
practices, and analyze their applicability to Bangladesh focusing on the generation 
subsector. 
(iii)  Consult with various stakeholders, including the Government, its agencies, labor 
unions,  consumers,  potential  international  and  domestic  private  investors  and 
financiers, and DPs; and examine and summarize their views and suggestions on 
promoting private sector participation and PPP in the power sector. 
(iv)  Analyze current and past PPP initiatives of Dhaka Electric Supply Company Limited 
(DESCO) and other distribution entities at management and operation levels, such 
as outsourcing related activities; evaluate the performance and recommend further 
enhancement. 
(v)  Review existing procedures and practices of the Government for processing and 
implementation of PPP projects to identify measures in improving their efficiency.

8  Appendix 3 
 
 
(vi)  Based on the above analysis, prepare recommendations for updating PSPGP and 
relevant  laws  and  regulations  to  promote  private  sector  participation  and  PPP 
modalities  in  the  entire  power  sector  covering  generation,  transmission,  and 
distribution. 
(vii)  Suggest measures to enhance investors’ credibility for implementation of power 
sector reform plans in Bangladesh, focusing on the generation subsector.  
(viii)  Recommend roles of the Government and power sector entities as well as the 
organizational setup to efficiently and effectively promote private sector participation 
and implement PPP projects.  
(ix)  Develop  PPP  guidelines  in  line  with  the  suggested  PSPGP  updates  to  guide 
relevant  authorities  in:  identification,  due  diligence  review,  bidding  and  contract 
awarding, and implementation of PPP projects. Such PPP guidelines should cover, 
but not be limited to, the following subjects: 
 
(a)  clear delineation of responsibilities between the Government and private                
participants under each PPP structure, 
(b)  bidding procedures and key criteria in selecting private participants, 
(c)  revenue  or  return  sharing  and  risk  allocation  mechanisms  between  the 
Government and private participants, 
(d)  basis and factors to be considered for project finance, and 
(e)  legal issues that must be considered when drawing up various kinds of                    
agreements and other legal documents governing the relationship. 
 
(x)  Recommend  a  coordination  mechanism  and  implementation  process,  with 
references to the PPP guidelines, for preparing, assessing, and implementing power 
projects. 
(xi)  Organize workshops, seminars, and consultation meetings to brief stakeholders and 
receive their feedback on the policy update, PPP guidelines, and the proposed PPP 
models in collaboration with ADB, MPEMR, BPDB, and other relevant agencies.  
(xii)  Prepare  a  report  that  summarizes  findings  on  the  issues  above  and  act  as  a 
resource person for such seminars and workshops in Dhaka. 
 
B.  Project Financing Expert (international, 6 person-months) 
 
6.  The terms of reference are as follows:  
 
(i)  Conduct diagnostic analysis of all the independent power producers (IPPs), small 
power plants, and PPP projects that have been planned or are operating in the 
Bangladesh power generation subsector since 1994; summarize the scope, financial 
structure,  and  issues;  and  evaluate  successes  or  failures  of  project  design, 
implementation, and operation. Analyze bottlenecks and constraints at the stage of 
financial structuring, contract awarding, construction, and operation.   
(ii)  Summarize international best practices in financing structuring of PPP projects in 
generation in both developing and developed countries, including mitigation of all 
kinds of risks related to PPP project and contract award methodologies—to avoid 
unnecessary interventions and improve transparency and competition. Draw any 
lessons that can be applicable for Bangladesh. 
(iii)  Analyze  how  products  and  services  of  DPs,  including  ADB,  can  be  utilized  in 
financial structuring for potential generation and distribution projects.

Appendix 3  9 
 
 
(iv)  Provide  at  least  two  PPP  models,  which  are  suitable  to  Bangladesh,  in  the 
generation and distribution subsectors respectively. Each PPP model should include, 
but not be limited to, the following items: 
 
(a)  clear delineation of responsibilities between the Government and private 
participants under each PPP structure; 
(b)  bidding procedures and key criteria in selecting private participants, 
(c)  revenue  or  return  sharing  and  risk  allocation  mechanisms  between  the                
Government and private participants; 
(d)  basis and factors to be considered for project finance; and 
(e)  legal issues that must be considered when drawing up various kinds of                    
agreements and other legal documents governing the relationship.  
 
(v)  In consultation with the relevant power sector entities, prepare a time-bound road 
map to implement these models for specific projects. 
 
C.  Power Sector Development Expert (national, 8 person-months) 
 
7.  The terms of reference are as follows:  
 
(i)  Assist the international power sector development expert to conduct all the tasks 
stated  above,  especially  in  collecting  relevant  data  and  information  and 
consultations with various domestic stakeholders.  
 
D.  Legal Expert (national, 6 person-months) 
 
8.  The terms of reference are as follows:  
 
(i)  Analyze related laws and regulations, with a perspective on the state of crucial laws 
and their key elements such as related to property rights, contractual rights, law of 
associations, and others.  
(ii)  Draft  changes  to  be  incorporated  in  existing  policies,  laws,  and  regulations  to 
facilitate introduction of PPP models. 
(iii)  Analyze costs of doing business and transactions; the capacity and quality of the 
public institutions responsible for planning and implementing the policy, laws, and 
regulations; and perspective on state of crucial laws and their key elements such as 
related to property rights, contractual rights, law of associations, and others. 
(iv)  Examine sector-related governance issues and prepare recommendations. 
 
E.  Financial Expert (national, 6 person-months) 
 
9.  The terms of reference are as follows:  
 
(i)  Assist the international project financing expert to conduct all the tasks stated above, 
especially in collecting relevant data and information and consultations with various 
domestic stakeholders.
